title: A Review of H.I.P.
short_summary: This article provides a firsthand account of the Hacking In Progress (HIP) conference, highlighting its unique atmosphere, diverse attendees, and various activities that fostered collaboration and learning among hackers and enthusiasts.
summary: The article offers an engaging narrative of the Hacking In Progress (HIP) conference, which took place in Europe and attracted around 2500 attendees from various backgrounds, including hackers, artists, and even law enforcement. The author describes the event as a carnival-like gathering where participants exchanged ideas, attended lectures on topics like computer security and cryptography, and engaged in hands-on workshops, such as lock-picking and social engineering. The atmosphere was notably positive, with a mature crowd that respected the event and its organizers, contrasting with the chaotic behavior often seen at other hacker conventions.
historical_context: The HIP conference marked a significant moment in hacker culture, showcasing a more mature and socially aware hacker community in Europe compared to the often juvenile antics seen in American hacker gatherings. It also highlighted the increasing involvement of women in technology and hacking, as well as the shifting perception of hackers from criminals to advisors in technology-related matters.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and anyone interested in the evolution of hacker culture and community events.
